title: Japanese village struggles to drive away macaques from residential areas | The World | ABC NEWS
description: Among Japan's many tourist draws hundreds of macaque monkeys roaming through its northern alps remain very popular. Locals, however, see them as pests. Despite huge efforts to drive the animals out of residential areas, there are growing calls to cull them. But as Manny Tsigas reports, some are calling that plan short-sighted. #ABCTheWorld #ABCAsiaPacific  Subscribe: http://ab.co/1svxLVE  ABC NEWS provides around the clock coverage of news events as they break in Australia and abroad. description: China's foreign ministry is calling for Japanese Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi to retract her recent suggestion that Japan could respond with its own self-defence force if China attacked Taiwan. title: Why New Zealanders are leaving in record numbers and moving to Australia | The World | ABC News
description: New migration data shows a record number of people are leaving new Zealand, and most are choosing to move to Australia. It's prompted fears of a brain drain, as workers look for opportunities they say aren't available at home. Professor Paul Spoonley, a sociologist from Massey University in Auckland, tells The World's Girish Sawlani why things are looking greener elsewhere for New Zealanders. #ABCTheWorld #ABCAsiaPacific  Subscribe: http://ab.co/1svxLVE  ABC NEWS provides around the clock coverage of news events as they break in Australia and abroad. title: Should neo-Nazis be banned from protesting? | ABC News Daily podcast
description: How is it that a neo-Nazi rally targeting Jewish people was allowed to take place on the steps of the New South Wales parliament?¬†   Why is it that the same group of people, who want a 'white Australia', could be allowed to form a political party?   Today, extremism expert Josh Roose explains the tactics neo-Nazi groups are using to skirt the law and continue to build their brand.¬†   He outlines why even in a liberal democracy where extremism is often tolerated, it might be time to think about ways to ban the movement.¬†   Featured:¬†   Josh Roose, extremism expert and an associate professor in politics at Deakin University

title: Family still waiting for answers on whether father's death linked to Optus outage | ABC News
description: The family of a Perth man whose death was tied to the Optus Triple Zero outage claims authorities left them in the dark for weeks and are still unsure how his death was connected to the telco failure. title: Prosecutor requests 210 years' prison for Aussie brothers' accused killers | ABC NEWS
description: A prosecutor has requested jail sentences of more than 200 years for the men accused of murdering Australian brothers Jake and Callum Robinson in Mexico last year. Three men ‚Äî who can be identified as Jes√∫s Gerardo, also known as "El Kekas," Irineo Francisco and √Ångel Jes√∫s ‚Äî have appeared in court in the Mexican city of Ensenada. Prosecutor Raul Covo Montejano requested 210-year jail sentences for each of the three men, who are all charged with aggravated homicide. The brothers and their American friend, Carter Rhoad, were killed while on a surfing trip in Baja California, along Mexico's Pacific coast, in April last year. Jake, a 31-year-old doctor from Perth, had travelled to the US to meet up with his brother Callum, 32, who had been living in America for 12 years after moving over to play lacrosse. They then travelled south to Mexico to go camping and surfing.  ABC NEWS provides around the clock coverage of news events as they break in Australia and abroad. title: Bali's Kelingking Beach glass elevator stops construction | ABC NEWS
description: A controversial 182-metre glass lift has taken shape on Bali's Kelingking Beach for 18 months. Last week, the provincial government suspended the works as it assesses the project's permits. If the project is cancelled, it is unclear how long it will take to remove the construction.  üì∏ via ABC News by Indonesia correspondent, Timothy Swanston  ABC NEWS provides around the clock coverage of news events as they break in Australia and abroad. title: 15 ACT schools closed after asbestos found in recalled coloured sand | ABC NEWS
description: Fifteen public schools in Canberra are closed today and several others are partially closed due to potential asbestos contamination. The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission earlier issued a national recall notice for decorative coloured sand products after testing detected traces of asbestos. Testing is underway at the ACT schools. On Sunday afternoon, a decision will be made about the schools resuming for Monday. A hotline has been established for questions about the the responses in public schools: (02) 6205 5429. title: How will Tasmania's new pet-friendly renting legislation work? | ABC NEWS
description: Starting from early next year, landlords in Tasmania will not be able to stop renters from owning pets unless they have a "reasonable" rationale backed by an independent tribunal.  The law change represents a big shift for Tasmania's rental landscape, where currently fewer than 20 per cent of advertised rentals say they will consider applicants with pets. title: France honours victims of deadly Islamic State Paris attacks 10 years on | ABC NEWS
description: France has paid tribute to the 130 people killed in 2015 during a rampage by Islamic State gunmen and suicide bombers targeting cafes, restaurants and the Bataclan concert hall. A November 13 Memory Garden has been unveiled to honour the victims and mark 10 years since the terror attack. French President Emmanuel Macron says France is still hurting.
